summary: This document is a chain of emails between Assistant U.S. Attorneys and defense attorney Lori Barrist regarding scheduling a discovery conference in the Clark case, which appears to be related to Jeffrey Epstein. The emails discuss scheduling conflicts and speculate that Epstein may be considering a plea deal.

persons.name: Lori Barrist
persons.context: Defense attorney being contacted to schedule a discovery conference in the Clark case; indicates she is out of town and will meet with her client (likely Epstein) the week of August 4.

persons.name: Joe Carmack
persons.context: Copied on an email from Lori Barrist regarding the discovery conference scheduling.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced indirectly as 'Epstein' in an email speculating about a potential plea deal and scheduling impact.

connections.description: Lori Barrist is indicated to be meeting with 'the d' (likely the defendant, Epstein) the week of August 4, suggesting she is his defense attorney.
Prosecutor and defense attorney corresponding to schedule a discovery conference in the Clark/Epstein case.

events.title: Email Exchange on Clark Discovery Conference
events.description: Series of emails discussing scheduling a discovery conference for the Clark case, with speculation that Epstein may be considering a plea deal.

events.title: Planned Client Meeting
events.description: Lori Barrist states she will be back the week of August 4 and will meet with her client (likely Epstein) that week.

keyFacts: The emails discuss scheduling a discovery conference for the 'Clark' case, which appears connected to Jeffrey Epstein.
An Assistant U.S. Attorney speculates that Epstein may be considering a plea deal ('Sounds like this may be a plea').
The prosecutor expresses a strategic concern about not letting defense attorney Lori Barrist 'get a look at her before trial,' suggesting a key witness or victim.
Lori Barrist indicates she will meet with her client (referred to as 'the d') the week of August 4, 2008.
